FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
NuGet.org will begin requiring two-factor authentication for accounts starting March 8th.
The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: NuGet API return Blob was not found" (#9111) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
@kalirajanganeshan commented on [Wed Apr 27 2022](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11780)

### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

Syncfusion Blazor Version API

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

We try to get the versions of our package using following NuGet API. It was return as blob was not founded but the package was exists in NuGet.Org.

API URL : https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/PackageName/index.json

Result:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87634016/165754482-b166de4f-026b-4ea1-abd0-8e8805e236b3.png)

Note: The issue was not occurred in all machine and it was only occurred in some machines only. Could you please check and update?


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Nuget SDK Resolver support for wildcard characters" (#11783) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "[Bug]: NuGet does not retry some HTTP timeouts" (#11779) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

dotnet 7.0 previews

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

NuGet's `HttpRetryHandler` has a `catch (OperationCancelledException) { throw; }` block in order to not retry when the input `cancellationToken` requests cancellation. However, `HttpClient` throws `OperationCancelledException` for some timeouts. This should be handled correctly with a `when (cancellationToken.IsCancellationRequested)` filter.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Add tracing to NuGet to identify all possible sources of package downloads" (#11782) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe, NuGet SDK

### The Elevator Pitch

Component Governance is important to help identify potential vulnerabilities in a repository.

Today component governance detects direct references, but also side-effects of restore -- the assets file, packages downloaded, binaries in the output.  These are all good indicators but sometimes are hard to trace to the root cause.

One example we've noticed that's exceptionally hard for folks to identify is eclipsed packages.  NuGet will download packages in the graph if it cannot "know" at the time of the download if that package will eventually win or not.  These packages will appear in a local packages folder and *could* be used by the repository, so they are flagged by component governance.

Take one example which we hit in some dotnet repositories.  Imagine package C1 is vulnerable and flagged by component governance.
```
Project > A > B1 > C1
Project > D > B2 > C2
```

In this case there is nothing inside the repository's intermediates that tells the repo owner "why" NuGet downloaded C1.  They could find the reference in other packages downloaded and try to walk back up to some package which does appear in intermediate assets files, but that's a ton of work and not really feasible for the majority of our users.

Can we make it *crystal clear* why a package was downloaded?  Potentially through opt-in tracing?  NuGet knows this information and can make it available through some simple logging.  Doing so would save repo owners everywhere many hours of time and make the ecosystem better by helping folks make more educated decisions in their repos around dismissing issues, working around them, or asking dependencies to update.



### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[DCR]: dotnet list package --outdated exit code" (#11781) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

We'd like to check for outdated packages as part of our PR pipeline.

We would like to use `dotnet list package --outdated`, however there is no way to tell (without parsing the output), if there are any outdated packages.

Would it be possible to opt into returning a non-zero exit code if there are outdated packages, so we can then fail our pipeline / report on it?



### Desired Behavior

Have an additional argument to `dotnet list package --outdated` to have it return a non-zero exit code if there are outdated packages (e.g., then number of outdated packages)

### Additional Context

Original issue https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/25091

We're currently using [dotnet-outdated/dotnet-outdated](https://github.com/dotnet-outdated/dotnet-outdated), however sometimes it is a hit or miss, because it fails to load the .sln.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org" (#61) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: We announced plans to require tFA on all accounts on NuGet.org. Details in the [blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/requiring-two-factor-authentication-on-nuget-org/).
